title.narrative: IFC / WBG privat sektor och handelsrådgivande program i Liberia
IFC/WBG Private Sector and Trade Advisory Programs in Liberia

description.narrative: The International Finance Corporation (IFC) 2019-2022 Advisory Service Program seeks to support the development of Liberia’s private sector through agriculture value chain development, trade facilitation, increased access to finance, and an improved business climate. Proposed interventions under this program aim to improve access to markets for Liberia’s budding private sector. The intervention has the following objectives within its different thematic areas. The overall objective of the IFC Private Sector Development and Trade Advisory Services intervention is to support the growth of Liberia’s private sector by creating new market linkages for investment in agriculture value-chain development – addressing financial sector stability challenges, facilitating trade, and addressing economy-wide constraints that are hampering economic growth. The above overall objective is broken down into four specific objectives: To link agro-producers, agro-processors, and markets to increase revenue and investment. At the same time, the project will address the binding constraints that impede private sector participation in selected agricultural sectors. To reduce import and export times and costs by making processes transparent and predictable, while also improving access to markets for agribusinesses. To increase access to finance throughout Liberia and especially in rural areas by assisting the build-out of mobile banking platforms. To support the government and the private sector in reforming key indicators to attract investments and decrease challenges to operating in the private sector in Liberia.

International Finance Corporation (IFC) har sökt stöd, 6 105 263 USD (cirka 55 MSEK), för att genomföra ett privata sektorn- och handelsrådgivande program kallat "Creating, and Expanding Markets Through Agriculture Value Chain Development, Trade, Access to Finance, and an Improved Business Climate" under perioden 2019-2022 som syftar till att skapa och expandera marknaderna genom utveckling av jordbruksvärdekedjor, handel, tillgång till finansiering och förbättrad affärsklimat. Den föreslagna insatsen bygger på eller kompletterar tidigare stöd som ambassaden har finansierat för IFCs program ”Investment Climate Reform and Private Sector Development” i Liberia mellan 2010 och 2016. Det övergripande målet med den föreslagna insatsen är att utveckla den privata sektorn med särskild inriktning på att diversifiera ekonomin genom värdekedjeutveckling inom jordbruket, handelstillämpning, ökad tillgång till finansiering och förbättring av affärsklimatet.

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) has requested 6,105,263 USD, approximately 55 MSEK, to implement a private sector and trade advisory programme during 2019-2022 that is aimed at creating and expanding markets through agriculture value chain development, trade, access to finance, and improved business climate. The proposed intervention builds on or compliments previous Embassy of Sweden support to IFC Investment Climate Reform and Private Sector Development programme in Liberia between 2010 and 2016.The proposed intervention overall objective is to develop the private sector with specific focus on diversifying the economy through agriculture value chain development, trade facilitation, increasing access to finance, and improving the business climate.

participating-org.narrative: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank

tag.narrative: 8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The year under review for this intervention was marked mainly with a pre-implementation phase and various scoping missions meant to clarify the actual parameters of the program. A key deliverable for the first six months of the project was the submission of a pre- implementation report by IFC, which was approved by the embassy with some observations, conclusions and way forwards transmitted to IFC. The findings reported below are results of various scoping missions, which primarily form the results of main activities undertaken during the year. Agriculture Value Chain Development: High-quality information and up-to-date material on specific sub-sectors (including production,markets, actors, and costs) is needed. Experts – with strong knowledge of Liberian agribusiness dynamics and context – exist and are available to support the project. Government counterparts and institutions potentially have vested interests in some sub-sectors which might pose conflict of interest. Poorly organized value chains – including limited tradeable surpluses, poor product competitiveness, absence of quality standards, tensions between the Ministry of Commerce and the Ministry of Agriculture, and poorly managed expectations in terms of the warehouse receipt system (WRS) – negatively impact the agricultural sector. Lack of liquidity to finance warehouse receipts. Recent reforms undertaken by LACRA may need revisiting. Trade Facilitation Liberia’s approach to trade reforms seems disjointed. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry (MoCI) is very active in promulgating trade regulations, but it seems to be working in isolation, without collaboration with other government agencies. The National Port Authority (NPA) is taking a similarly isolated approach. The recent Cargo Tracking Note (CTN) was introduced without the National Bureau of Customs’ consent or knowledge. There seems to be a challenge with National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC) implementation. MoCI serves as the committee’s official chair, but the ministry has shown no real interest in proceeding with post-World Trade Organization accession activities. Customs should likely assume the leadership, but MoCI is reluctant to relinquish that position. Financial Inclusion Government officials and market participants have different opinions on market development – some want to develop a securities framework as a first step, while others want to let transactions take place before developing a framework. Based on the team's three-year engagement with the central bank, the institution has a clear commitment to advancing digital credit. The Ministry of Finance has demonstrated clear support for advancing digital payments; this momentum is a great starting point for the IFC engagement. Banks continue to show interest in establishing agents in the agency banking model and have already established 53 agents in first year. IFC can certainly build on this momentum and help them to expand this across the country. Business Climate Reform No one is currently analysing the potential impact of new policies or reforms in Liberia. The approach to reforms appears sporadic, with very little coordination, even within the government. The government has been very uncooperative with the private sector as it introduces new regulations. There is very little or no consultation with the private sector prior to the introduction of reforms. The overall business climate has deteriorated significantly since the new administration came to power in 2018. Very little trust exists between the government and the private sector; the private sector is quite reluctant to engage with the government, as stakeholders have not seen any concrete results from recent engagements. The Ministry of Finance appears to be interested in improving the business climate, with minister himself expressing a desire for IFC to support the ministry. The project will count on the minister’s support and will propose that he serves as the reform champion within the government.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
